column4: What will take longer time to partition a 160 GB hard disk for Windows and Ubuntu: Gparted or cfdisk?
cfdisk needs abt 5 seconds
And why does GParted tell me that in needs > 3 hours?
idk, i never used gparted
thats why i talked only about cfdisk :)
and btw, you asked for partitioning, not for creating a filesystem (which cfdisk won't do)
Ah! That is an important point of view. --  Thank you for pointing me at that.
your news-account password
And where do I know this news-account password from?
seems to be pan-issue, slrn/thunderbird don't ask when accessing news.gmane.org
Thank you very much for commenting.
accidently checkd "server requires authorization" box?
I will check that immediately now.
Where is the box "server requires authorization" to be found in Pan?
i never used pan, according to the screenshots on their website, at "server-setting" tab
Do you mean this website? http://pan.rebelbase.com/
yes http://pan.rebelbase.com/screenshots/servers.png

The layout of my two Pan server windows deviates a little bit from what you have shown me but is basically the same as the windows which you showed me. I am using Pan version 0.133. But there is no box "Server requires authorization" provided. So I filled in my name and a password which I selected deliberately. But I do not get access to news.gmane.org.
no more ideas then, sorry
Ok, thank you.
reinstalled "libzvbi0"?
libzvbi0 is not installed. Why should I install it?
sorry typo, meant someone else
they exist to make win-users feel like home, just meta-directories
At least they either keep or change their names if I change the locale. How is this feature implemented in tem?
What is a meta-directory?
sorry, no idea about how that mechanism works, i always delete them after installation.
Right. --  Thank you for explaining.
~/.profile and .bashrc (read man bash)
'man bash' does not even mention 'configuration'.
it lists files which are read, depending on invocation. that are the "configfiles"
I found these files now under the heading 'FILES'.  --  Thank you for explaining.
read part "invokation" to see in which case what file will be read
$ gpg --list-public-keys
'~$ gpg --list-public-keys' lists pub, uid and sub of several persons. This list is the 'public keyring'?
basically yes
Is there also a 'private' keyring on my Ubuntu 9.10 computer?
$ gpg --list-secret-keys
man gpg for further help
Thank you very much for your help.
that user would be used to run ircd
that group too
What is ircd?
an irc daemon
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IRCd
Thank you very much for your help.
if you prefer to "cd" into all those working-dirs, you should make sure not to have "." in your $PATH
I agree with you. But I rather prefer to leave the . where it is and act acoordingly depening on my current job at hand.
/usr/lib/xorg/modules/input/synaptics_drv.so

/usr/lib/xorg/modules/input/synaptics_drv.so is a "shared object". 'Shared' means that several programs will use it. What programs will use the shared object /usr/lib/xorg/modules/input/synaptics_drv.so?
at least the xserver
If it is only the xserver, why is synaptics_drv.so driver provided in the "shared object" format?
idk, sorry. i guess theres more that needs  access to hardware using it, but i'mm not so familiar with the internal organisation of X
Thank you very much for your help.
there should be documentation about that at www.x.org
ok.
there is nothing like "fsck.swap"
not associated ~ not connected to an AP (or has no APs essid)  AP=AccessPoint
Thank you very much for your help. I appreciate it.
listening port 111 (grep sunrpc /etc/services)
netstat -an   to get ports listed
ohsix: Thank you very much for your help.
hostid != ip-address even if its calculated from it
Of course 'hostid != ip-address'. This is trivial because hostid is a command and no address in my question. But this does not anser my question.
it does. what "hostid" gives you is a random number (mostly generated from ip-addresses/mac-addr). gethostip prints the IP of a given host.

You say:"what "hostid" gives you is a random number (mostly generated from ip-addresses/mac-addr)". Your statement contradicts 'man hostid': "hostid prints the numeric identifier for the current host."
numeric identifier is just a unique number to identify a host. thats the purpose of hostid.  read man-pages (2) for gethostid/sethostid

I presume that you meant "read man-pages (3)" and not "read man-pages (2). -- '~$ man 2 gethostid' says: "sethostid()  sets a unique 32-bit identifier for the current machine.  The 32-bit identifier is intended to be unique among all Unix systems in existence.  This normally resembles the Internet address for the local machine, as returned by gethostbyname(3), and thus usually never...
just to identify a machine, some software-licenses use it. and no, i meant "man 2 gethostid/sethostid"

Ah! Thank you for explaining. --  A minor supplementing question: If I tpye 'man 2 gethostid' Maverick will present a page headlined: "GETHOSTID(3), Linux Programmer's Manual, GETHOSTID(3)." Why changes the digit 2 to 3?
seems its the same page in section 2 and 3, i don't know
Thank you again very much for your help.
sorry for very late response, if you're still interested: nmap -sP <network>      where network is like "192.168.1.0/24"   if you use 192.168.1.xxx ip-range with netmask 255.255.255.0
Yes indeed: I tried it in the mean time,  and it works great. --  Thank you very much for your help.
but even that won't find hosts filtering ICMP. afaik there is no perfect solution to find all hosts in a network except using special switches or other expensive hardware
In my (rather simple) case it worked. --  What do you mean by "special switches"? Hardware or software switches?
manageable switches often have functions to list all connected hosts
Yes. Thank you for explaining.
you want to read the part "Funktionsweise am Beispiel Ethernet"
/j ##networking
Thank you.
ps aux|head -1     tells you what the columns are
#NX
Thank you very much for your help.
I managed to join. --  Thank you very much for your help.
used sudo?
No. I wil repeat but using sudo.

: "~$ sudo lsof | grep /var/log/kern.log; [sudo] password for detlef: ***; lsof: WARNING: can't stat() fuse.gvfs-fuse-daemon file system /home/detlef/.gvfs;  Output information may be incomplete. rsyslogd    815      syslog    5w      REG        8,6   425596     292906 /var/log/kern.log.'  --  Thank you very much for your help.
Installing the DEB program package »sysklogd« would install the daemons sysklogd and klogd and apparently deinstall rsyslogd. What is the advantage of such an endeavour?
i don't see any advantage, imho rsyslogd is much user-friendlier and does a good job
Ah! Thank you very much for your judgement.
syslogd/klogd are much older and were used in most distros over years. thats why most howtos/docs refer to it
I see.
better ask canonical directly
How can I ask Canonical directly?
canonical.com - contact or supprt
I dont think that thisl little comprehension problem of mine justifies to ask Canonical for support.
if you click the link you mentioned and read "Register for your free trial of Ubuntu Advantage"  it sounds like you have to pay (sooner or later). but thats offtopic here
I've got the same impression. --  Thank you.
